The emergence of artiﬁcial intelligence ethics auditing

This research paper investigates the rapidly developing field of artificial intelligence (AI) ethics and governance auditing. The study, based on an interview-based analysis of 34 individuals across seven countries, explores the motivations, activities, and challenges within this emerging ecosystem. The core finding is that AI ethics audits largely mirror financial auditing stages but suffer from a lack of comprehensive stakeholder engagement, clear success metrics, and external reporting. The audits are predominantly concentrated on technical aspects of AI ethics, specifically bias, privacy, and explainability, driven by a regulatory focus on technical risk management. A significant challenge identified is the competing demands across various interdisciplinary functions within organizations, coupled with resource constraints – including staff shortages and inadequate technical infrastructure. Furthermore, the auditors grapple with considerable ambiguity regarding regulatory interpretation due to the scarcity of established best practices and practical regulatory guidance. The research highlights the crucial, albeit nascent, role that AI ethics and governance auditors are currently playing in the initial stages of implementing ethical considerations within the AI landscape. The study underscores the need for improved frameworks, clearer standards, and greater investment in supporting infrastructure to facilitate more effective and robust AI ethics audits. The lack of standardized measurement and reporting mechanisms represents a key weakness in the current approach, suggesting a need for more formalized methodologies to assess and demonstrate the impact of ethical audits. The paper’s findings contribute to a better understanding of the complexities involved in navigating this evolving field and provide valuable insights for organizations and regulators seeking to promote responsible AI development and deployment.

artificial intelligence ethics auditing AI ethics regulatory efforts bias privacy explainability stakeholder involvement technical risk management audit risk assessment
